div1.p: A WORLD BENEFACTOR

Yet Major Reed Died Unre-
warded By Government.
FOUND CAUSE OF A SCOURGE

It Was He Who Discovered That
Yellow Fever Is Transmitted By
Mosquitoes--Dr. Sternberg's Tests.
[Special Dispatch to the Baltimore Sun.]

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Dr. Charles M.
Ellis, of Elkton, Md., in a very timely and
appropriate communication to THE SUN re-
cently called public attention to the serv-
ices of Major Walter Reed, who died some
weeks ago in Washington.

That favors and rewards do not always
go to those most deserving, particularly in
the military and naval branches of the
Government, is conspicuously demonstrated
in the case of the late Major Walter Reed,
a distinguished surgeon of the army and a
leading scientist of the day. For far less
service to their country and humanity men
were made major-generals and brigadiers
during the Spanish War, and at its close,
while Major Reed's work was unrecognized
by the Government in any shape except in
the perfunctory communications of con-
gratulations which he may have received
from his superior officers at the War De-
partment. The fact that Major Reed proved
through careful and painstaking investiga-
tion yellow fever was communicated to
persons through the bite of the mosquito
is now generally accepted by the medical
world, but his own Government has passed
by his work and triumphant success with-
out reward or public recognition. He was
not advanced a single number, or even
brevetted.
Reward On Field Of Battle.

An officer who rendered even some moder-
ate service on the field of battle would un-
questionably be rewarded in a general or-
der published to his command, and perhaps
later receive additional rank. While the
medical men of the army gave valuable
services, as a rule, during the Spanish War,
recognition in the shape of higher rank and
pay went to none except Leonard Wood,
who jumped from an assistant surgeon and
captain to the rank of major-general in less
than two years, although at the time serv-
ing as a volunteer of the line and not at-
tached to the Medical Corps. Of Major
Reed's work in the medical department
and his scientific researches it is probable
a complete history never can be obtained.
His eminence as a bacteriologist and in
practical hygiene as applied to military life
led to his being intrusted with special in-
vestigations, which were interrupted by
his death and it is now believed will never
be completed. He was regarded by his as-
sociates as a man who combined and un-
usual degree of scientific accuracy with
calm judgment, which rendered him invalu-
able in searching out the cause of epi-
demic diseases and tracing their progress.
Begins Yellow-Fever Inquiry.

In 1900 he began the investigation of the
cause of the prevalence of yellow fever,
conducting the investigation at Quemados,
near Havana, where he established head-
quarters and was given every facility for
carrying on his experiments. The condi-
tions in Cuba were such as made the in-
vestigations of Major Reed and his corps
of assistants of special moment. An epi-
demic of yellow fever existed despite the
efforts of the sanitary experts. The houses
of persons infected were subjected to rigid
disinfection. Furniture was destroyed and
every possible precaution was taken to
prevent the spread of the disease under
the old treatment. Major Reed became con-
vinced that proper sanitation was not all
that was needed. He believed that some
agency other than accumulation of filth
was responsible for the spread of the dis-
ease and his attention was attracted to the
fact that it took much longer for a house
to become infected than the usual time of
incubation. This suggested a biting insect
as an intermediate host of the parasite,
and he asked and promptly received from
General Wood permission to make experi-
ments with mosquitoes as the conveyers of
yellow fever and a liberal supply of money
for these experiments. By these experi-
ments it was determined beyond question
that through a certain species of mos-
quito the yellow-fever germ was dissemi-
nated.
Dr. Sternberg's Experiments.

For several years prior to the discovery
that the mosquito conveyed the infection of
yellow fever research and investigation had
been made into the causes of the disease by
Dr. George M. Sternberg, lately Surgeon-
General of the army and a well-known
scientist on this special branch of bac-
teriology. General Sternberg's investiga-
tions had been conducted for several years
in Havana, Central and South America and
later at the Johns Hopkins University, Bal-
more, and in New York, and later, when he
came to Washington, were continued by his
chief assistant at a Brooklyn laboratory
over which he presided. It was not until
the summer of 1897, however, that the ques-
tion received the consideration which final-
ly culminated in the wonderful discoveries
made by the board of which the late Major
Reed was president. General Sternberg be-
lieving the question deserving the utmost
consideration, in view of its ravages yearly
in tropical countries and the constant men-
ace Cuba was to ports of the Southern
States, designated a board of officers, con-
sisting of Major Reed and Contract Sur-
geon James Carroll, then stationed here at
the Medical Museum, to begin the impor-
tant work of investigating the germ ques-
tion as relating to yellow fever.
Sanarelli's Bacillus.

About that time the famous Italian yel-
low fever expert, Sanarelli, who had been
conducting investigation in the yellow fever
districts of South America, reported that
he had discovered the bacillus which he
believed was the cause of yellow fever and
which he had named “bacillus icteroides.”
Naturally so important an announcement
to the medical world caused considerable
interest and among some members of the
medical profession it was believed the real
cause of yellow fever had been definitely
traced. General Sternberg, whose atten-
tion was drawn to the statement, had cul-
tures preserved of the only organism iso-
lated by him to which any special signifi-
cance might be attached. That year he was
appointed a delegate to the meeting of medi-
cal men held at St. Petersburg, where the
subject of yellow fever received considera-
tion among numerous others discussed. Re-
turning by way of Paris, General Stern-
berg secured a culture of Sanarelli's bacil-
lus from Professor Roux, which he brought
home and sent to the Army Medical Mu-
seum for examination.

Major Reed and Dr. Carroll were desig-
nated to study it in conjunction with a
bacillus which General Sternberg had pre-
viously had sent on from Brooklyn for
study which he named bacillus “X.” Major
Reed and Dr. Carroll were indefatigable in
their examinations, but finally concluded
after study of the organisms that each be-
longed to a well-known group of bacteria--
bacillus “X” to the Colon group and bacil-
lus icteroides to the hog-cholera group.
Attention Given To Cuba.

This part of the work was not completed
until the spring of 1900. That summer yel-
low fever was as prevalent at Havana and
other Cuban ports, where it made its ap-
pearance with regularity every year. The
disease was a subject of serious thought to
the army medical men, because of the large
number of troops then stationed in the is-
land and the probability that they would
be continued there for a number of years.
In fact, yellow fever was then looked upon
as one of the most serious problems with
which the army had to deal, and it was
therefore incumbent upon the Medical Corps
to cope with it to the best of its ability. It
had been a serious menace to the troops
from the time they first set foot on Cuban
soil, and unless it could be checked or
stamped out entirely would always be a se-
rious problem for the soldiers to face. Gen-
eral Sternberg then decided upon the ap-
pointment of a board for the study of yel-
low fever and other tropical diseases and
selected for the president Major Reed,
whose work in that field probably rendered
him one of the best-qualified officers of the
service to conduct the investigation.
Sanarelli's Bacillus Absent.

Major Reed had associated with him Con-
tract Surgeons Carroll, Agramonte and La-
zear, the latter, a Baltimorean, sacrificing
his life in the interest of science. This
board studied the question for several
months and finally failed to find Sanarelli's
bacillus in any of the cases studied and,
abandoning that line of research, they took
up the subject of the mode of conveyance
of the disease. The prevailing idea had
been for years that yellow fever was con-
tagious and could be transmitted by con-
tact with a patient or through causes other
than inoculation. One of the first things de-
termined upon by the board was to prove
or disprove Sanarelli's claim for his bacil-
lus, which had been supported by others.

Failing to find Sanarelli's germ in a sin-
gle case, it became necessary to pursue
some other line of investigation, and the
mosquito theory advocated by Dr. Findlay
was next taken up. This was a most diffi-
cult matter, and it was not believed that
there would be many persons volunteering
to submit to this dangerous and perhaps
fatal test in the interest of medical science.
Surgeons Volunteer.

Dr. Carroll and Dr. Lazear volunteer to
submit themselves to the bite of a contam-
inated mosquito, and one week after be-
ing bitten Dr. Carroll was down with the
disease in a most severe form, from which
he recovered, however, early in September.
Dr. Lazear was taken ill of the disease on
September 18 of that year and died just
one week later. Another individual bitten
by the mosquito which had been applied
to Dr. Carroll suffered from a mild attack
of the disease and recovered. Major Reed
was then satisfied that the board had made
a most important discovery, and immedi-
ately the War Department and the medical
world were notified. Further experiments
were made several months later, all of
which went to prove the conclusions reached
by Major Reed that yellow fever was com-
municated by the mosquito bite and that
contact by a well person with one suffering
from the disease would not transmit the
disease. As a result of the discoveries made
by the Reed board it has been conclusively
proved, and is so accepted by the medical
men, that yellow fever is transmitted to
non-immune individuals by the bite of the
mosquito that has previously fed on the
blood of those ill with the disease.
Period Of Contamination.

It was proved also that an interval of
about 12 days or more after contamination
appears to be necessary before the mos-
quito is capable of conveying the infection,
and that the bite at an earlier period did
not appear to confer any immunity against
a subsequent attack. The spread of yellow
fever. It was concluded, can be most effect-
ually controlled by measures directed to
the destruction of mosquitoes and the pro-
tection of the sick against the bites of these
insects. While the mode of propagation of
yellow fever was definitely determined by
Major Reed the specific cause of the dis-
ease remains yet to be discovered.

Appreciating fully the importance of the
discovery. Major Reed decided in order to
exclude all other possible sources of in-
fection in future observations to establish
a special experimental station, where fur-
ther observation could be made of non-im-
mune human beings, both as to the propa-
gation of yellow fever by means of the bite
of the insect and by exposure to the most
intimate contact with infected clothing and
bedding, and this under the strictest en-
forcement of military quarantine.
Not Spread By Bed Clothing.

The station consisted of quite a large
house. An acting assistant surgeon and two
privates of the hospital corps entered the
building and exposed themselves in every
possible way to the contaminated linen and
bed clothing. The sheets and pillow cases
were used in preparing the beds in which
members of the hospital corps slept; va-
rious articles were hung around the room
and placed about the bed occupied by the
young surgeon. For 20 days this room was
occupied by the non-immunes, and after
being held in quarantine five days they
were liberated in perfect health. They had
in fact improved physically by their ex-
perience. Such experiments were continued
for several weeks, under direction of Major
Reed, and when finally the board withdrew
from the island the world knew positively
that an important discovery had been made
in medical science and that it was con-
clusively proved that the mosquito con-
veyed the yellow-fever germ.
Major Reed's Career.

This distinguished officer, Major Reed,
was a Virginian, having been born, as stated
in THE SUN at the time of his death, in
Gloucester county, September 13, 1851, and
graduated from the medical department of
the University of Virginia in 1869, and
Bellevue Hospital Medical College, New
York city, in 1872. He was appointed an
assistant surgeon June 26, 1875, and pro-
moted through the various grades until he
reached the rank of major, which he held
at the time of his death. The honors con-
ferred upon him by universities were many
and included the degree of bachelor of arts
by Harvard last June, at the time degrees
were conferred upon President Roosevelt
and Secretary Hay. About the same time
the degree of master of arts was conferred
upon Major Reed by the University of
Michigan at Ann Arbor. During his army
career he served at Willets Point, N. Y.:
Harrisonburg, Va.: on general recruiting
duty in the far West and at Fort McHenry,
Md., during the year 1881.
